In [[Greek mythology]], '''Thestius''' ({{lang-grc|Θέστιος}}) was the son of either [[Ares]] and [[Demonice]],<ref>Pseudo-[[Apollodorus of Athens|Apollodorus]], ''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]]'' 1. 7. 7</ref> or [[Agenor, son of Pleuron|Agenor]] (son of [[Pleuron (Greek mythology)|Pleuron]] son of [[Aetolus, son of Endymion|Aetolus]]) and [[Epicasta]].<ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]], ''Description of Greece'', 3. 13. 8</ref> He was the father of [[Iphicles]] with [[Leucippe]],<ref>[[Hyginus]], ''Fabulae'', 14</ref> or Deidameia, daughter of [[Perieres]],<ref>[[Scholia]] on [[Apollonius Rhodius]], ''Argonautica'', 201</ref> or else with [[Eurythemis]], daughter of [[Cleoboea]] and mother of his other children, [[Althaea (Greek mythology)|Althaea]], [[Eurypylus]], [[Evippus]], [[Hypermnestra]], [[Leda (mythology)|Leda]], [[Toxeus]] and [[Plexippus]].<ref>Pseudo-[[Apollodorus of Athens|Apollodorus]], ''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]]'' 1. 7. 10</ref> In one source though, the mother of Althaea and Leda is Laophonte, daughter of [[Pleuron (Greek mythology)|Pleuron]].<ref>[[Scholia]] on [[Apollonius Rhodius]], ''Argonautica'', 146</ref> Thestius was allied with [[Tyndareus]] and [[Icarius]] against [[Hippocoon]].<ref>Pseudo-[[Apollodorus of Athens|Apollodorus]], ''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]]'' 3. 10. 5</ref> He is not to be confused with [[Thespius]], who was sometimes referred to as "Thestius".<ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]], ''Description of Greece'', 9. 27. 7</ref> The [[patronymic]] "Thestias" may refer to one of his daughters, Leda or Althaea,<ref>[[Aeschylus]], ''[[Libation-Bearers]]'', 606</ref><ref>[[Euripides]], ''[[Iphigenia in Aulis]]'', 49</ref> and "Thestiades" to his son Iphicles.<ref>[[Apollonius Rhodius]], ''Argonautica'', 1. 261</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.mythindex.com/greek-mythology/T/Thestius.html Myth Index -
